Hi Ray,

>
> >...
> >Functional testing of API's have many of the same design and usage
> >patterns of any functional test tool out on the market. Keep in mind that
> >if tests have dependencies - you will effectively be blocked from
> >executing dependent tests when you encounter a failure. This has a bad
> >smell, weather you are doing functional, unit - or using a commercial tool
> >like Silk or LoadRunner. That being said, sometimes it does make sense to
> >couple test cases, or a series of test cases - but you need to understand
> >the tradeoffs before doing this.
>
> i agree about the bad smell, but i am looking at using junit, cactus,
> httpunit etc. to test some web apps. it seems that there are at least 3
> levels of tests from unit tests on each class to a functional test of a web
> app. and the associated dependencies. does anyon know how people have
> structured their tests in such cases?
>

I'm not sure I follow.  I generally use different isolated test suites for unit
vs. integration vs. acceptance tests.  The acceptance tests don't use the unit or
integration tests.  The integration tests don't use the unit tests.  Each type of
test is intended for different types of feedback at different frequencies.

Could you give an example?

Mike
